body: By all accounts, these are hard times for New York's City Council. By some accounts, the person primarily responsible is Thomas J. Cuite. Mr. Cuite, the small, slight, bespectacled vice chairman and majority leader, is blamed by many of his colleagues for what they see as the Council's sorry condition. In recent months, a Federal judicial panel
title: COUNCIL WOES PUT MAJORITY LEADER INTO THE SPOTLIGHT

body: More than a score of people were murdered in New York City during the three-day Christmas weekend in robberies, family fights, street and bar disputes and other, more mysterious circumstances, the police said yesterday. With the weekend's death toll, the final days of 1981 seemed likely to set a new record for homicides in New York City. The year's
title: SCORE OF WEEKEND MURDERS PUSH '81 TOLL NEAR RECORD

body: TODAY is a runner's dream. At the Verrazano Bridge, helicopters hover overhead. Network is there. Fireboats spout. A mass of human energy waits in a holding pattern. In a moments' notice, it surges forward, cascading like water through a broken dam, streaming forth endlessly into the streets of Bay Ridge. This morning, runners from all over the
title: A DAY THAT RUNS ON AND ON

body: Autumn is a season for falling leaves, hot cider, baseball playoffs and, it would seem, a multitude of educational house tours. And this weekend's crop of planned events is no exception. In fact, the tours scheduled for Saturday and Sunday will offer everything from real estate advice in Bedford-Stuyvesant to historic houses in Jersey City. ''Come
title: HOUSE TOURS FOR AN AUTUMN WEEKEND

body: With Harry B. Helmsley's announced withdrawal as the redeveloper of the Brooklyn Army Terminal, two civic associations that have long questioned the Helmsley approach called upon the Koch Administration anew to review the issue of how the property should be redeveloped. The two groups - the City Club and a Brooklyn citizens coalition called Keep
title: BROOKLYN ARMY TERMINAL STUDY ASKED

body: The extent of integration in New York City is a key factor in the dispute over redistricting. Pa ge B8. By ROBIN HERMAN The City Council hired a private lawyer and its staff labored over census maps yesterday to solidify the defense of a redistricting plan that is under attack by black and Hispanic groups as discriminatory. The city's failure to
title: COUNCIL TO FIGHT ON REDISTRICTING

body: New York City fire officials say that the arson rate in the city seems at least to be staying level, reversing a trend of the last five years. The annual number of determined arson fires in the city rose from 3,878 in 1975 to 8,979 in 1980. Although officials are hesitant to put too much stock in numbers, the Fire Department said 4,214 structural
title: CITY ARSON RATE IS LEVELING OFF, OFFICIALS REPORT

body: New York City has spent about $285 million in the last three years under its program to take over tax-delinquent apartment buildings, rehabilitate them and restore them to the tax rolls, but it has sold only 200 of the more than 10,000 it has acquired. More important, nonprofit community groups and tenant associations, which the city hoped would
title: CITY STRUGGLING IN ATTEMPTS TO SELL TAX-DELINQUENT APARTMENT BUILDINGS

body: Irate neighborhood groups and community associations from various sections of the city crowded into the auditorium of Public School 87 on West 78th Street yesterday to tell state and city officials in no uncertain words how they felt about the city's subway and bus service. The main target was Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan
title: RAVITCH AND WAGNER ASSAILED AT 'TRANSIT SPEAKOUT'

body: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that a starter's pistol turned over to the police by an 11-year-old Brooklyn boy was not the gun that investigators believe was used by the boy's 17-year-old friend to fire at an off-duty policeman in Brooklyn last week. The 17-year-old, Jose Mendez of the Bronx, was fatally shot by one of two
title: POLICE SAY GUN TURNED IN BY BOY ISN'T ONE THAT FIGURES IN KILLING

body: The fatal shooting of a 17-year-old alleged car thief by an offduty police officer in Brooklyn last Tuesday has provoked disagreement between some community residents and police investigators over whether the youth had a gun at the time the incident occurred. ''As far as we know now, this shooting was justified,'' Deputy Inspector Richard Olpe, who
title: OFFICER'S KILLING OF YOUTH: DID VICTIM HAVE A GUN?

body: A 27-year-old man who the police said was ''very unhappy'' about having been rejected by his girlfriend fatally shot the woman yesterday in a crowded midtown bank where she worked as a teller. The man was then fatally shot by an off-duty policeman. The rejected lover, Angelo Lopez, had gone to the Atlantic Bank of New York at 960 Avenue of the
title: MAN KILLS TELLER BEFORE HE IS SHOT BY POLICE OFFICER

body: A bullet removed from the right arm of an off-duty police officer who fatally shot a 17-year-old alleged car thief in Brooklyn on Tuesday could have come from a gun fired by the officer's partner at a moonlighting construction job, the police said last night. The caliber of the bullet is crucial to the investigation of the incident because
title: PARTNER MAY HAVE SHOT OFF-DUTY OFFICER

body: A 17-year-old youth in a stolen car was shot and killed by an offduty police officer who was moonlighting at a construction site in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the police said. Though there were conflicting accounts of the shooting, a Police Department spokesman said that no charges were brought against either of two off-duty officers involved,
title: Off-Duty Officer Kills A Boy, 17, in Brooklyn

body: John Kuhn left his wife behind and moved to the island of Grenada. David Spense had his sights set on Rome, but ended up in Ensenada, Mexico. Tom Rizzo saw an advertisement in a newspaper and went off to Tampico, Mexico. They went looking for medical school. Rejected years ago by medical programs in this country, they decided to fashion their own
title: STATE PANEL STUDIES TRAINING OF DOCTORS

body: For Elizabeth Davies, the New Year began with the kind of tenant headache that can be life-threatening for someone who is 77 years old: The heat went off in her Chelsea brownstone apartment for nine arctic days. Desperate, she bought an electric heater, which provided only limited comfort. ''It doesn't heat the whole room,'' she said, ''so you
title: AGED CAUTIONED ON HOW TO COPE WITH COLD SPELL

body: At 8:30 Tuesday night, Brendan Collins sat alone at the long brown admissions table just inside the National Guard Armory in Harlem. He was patiently mired in the accumulating chaos that had become familiar since the city and Red Cross opened the building last week as a shelter for those suffering from the cold. Behind him, set out for the night
title: NIGHTLY DRAMAS UNRAVEL AT CITY'S SHELTERS IN COLD

body: Complaints of heatless buildings mounted yesterday as New York City officials reported a ''substantial increase'' in the number of housing inspectors on duty and the bitter cold continued. The use of heating fuel in the metropolitan area soared as the city's temperature fell to 2 degrees and an Arctic air mass still hovered over the Northeast. City
title: HEAT COMPLAINTS AND USE OF FUEL BOTH SHOW RISE

body: Mayor Koch and Anthony B. Gliedman, New York City's Housing Commissioner, said yesterday that the city had restored heat and hot water to ''tens of thousands'' of tenants in 6,000 privately owned buildings so far this winter through its emergency repairs program. Speaking at a news conference at City Hall, Mr. Koch and Mr. Gliedman said the city's
title: CITY STRENGTHENS ITS EFFORTS TO ASSIST HEATLESS TENANTS

body: In recent years, relations between the Hispanic and Jewish residents of two neighboring Brooklyn communities have improved, thanks to two self-help groups, the Sunset Park Redevelopment Committee and the Southern Brooklyn Community Organization in nearby Borough Park. The peaceful coexistence will soon take on a new dimension. The groups will
title: Welcome Help for Self-Help
